pal 0.0.9090
  • Reference

Fuse regular expressions

Source: R/pal.gen.R
fuse_regex.Rd

Combines a vector or list of regular expressions to a single one (by logical OR).

fuse_regex(...)

Arguments

...

Regular expressions. All elements will be converted to type character before fusing. Dynamic dots are supported.

Value

A character scalar.

See also

The rex package which provides an intuitive framework to build complex regular expressions.

Other string functions: as_chr(), as_comment_string(), as_line_feed_chr(), as_string(), capitalize_first(), dsv_colnames(), escape_lf(), prettify_nr(), prose_ls(), sentenceify(), wrap_chr()

Examples

# \donttest{
# perform some (nonsense) Jane Austen text extraction
regex <- c("My dear Jane",
           "make haste, ",
           "(?i)\\bevil")

stringr::str_subset(string = janeaustenr::prideprejudice,
                    pattern = pal::fuse_regex(regex))# }
#>  [1] "Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.\""                     
#>  [2] "evil--a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.\""
#>  [3] "can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing"    
#>  [4] "evil.\""                                                                  
#>  [5] "to inevitable evils is the duty of us all; the peculiar duty of a"        
#>  [6] "\"My dear Jane!\" exclaimed Elizabeth, \"you are too good. Your sweetness"
#>  [7] "understanding than I now do of her heart. My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a" 
#>  [8] "wish him all manner of evil. But my feelings are not only cordial"        
#>  [9] "however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time" 
#> [10] "travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the"    
#> [11] "world; and no one could say how lasting an evil he might have inflicted." 
#> [12] "connection could not be so great an evil to my friend as to me. But"      
#> [13] "of pointing out to my friend the certain evils of such a choice. I"       
#> [14] "herself, was entirely insensible of the evil. Elizabeth had frequently"   
#> [15] "of particular, but of general evils, which I am now complaining. Our"     
#> [16] "over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her"   
#> [17] "unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising" 
#> [18] "greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all"      
#> [19] "good or evil must be done by him! Every idea that had been brought"       
#> [20] "kind of moral extractions from the evil before them."                     
#> [21] "\"You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone"    
#> [22] "it sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in"     
#> [23] "an evil which had been brought on by himself. If he _had another_"        
#> [24] "\"My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come--Mr. Bingley is"    
#> [25] "representation of the evils attached to a connection with her, she dared" 
#> [26] "Elizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur by a precipitate"    
#> [27] "there were other evils before her. She anticipated what would be felt"
